The Azure Rest API, or Rather Resource Management API

November 3, 2015

Let's start with a simple bingle search. Head over to duckduckgo.com and type in "Azure REST API" and hit quack...

The top hit is already leading you astray! It takes us to the Azure Service Management API (ASM). "Ian, why is that not right?", you ask? Well to be fair it's not wrong... but wait we want Azure Resource Manager (ARM). It's the latest hotness.

Let me take a step back here to say, I fall off of mountain bikes regularly, it's my excuse.

Dear Katniss Everdeen...

uhh, back to Azure.

ASM is like?.. Well my 2009 Pathfinder. It's trusty, and gets me to and fro, but doesn't have all the latest bells and whistles (Bluetooth!!!).  ARM is like?.. I want to say a Tesla, but that may be a little much. A NEW PATHFINDER! ha that would probably have Bluetooth.

ARM is where you should be focusing. Instead of crafting an ASM based URL with a POST method that looks something like:

https://management.core.windows.net//services/hostedservices//deployments

ref

With a body full of XML <digital shiver />. The 90's called wanting their code back... You should instead, create an ARM PUT that looks something like:

https://management.azure.com/subscriptions/{subscription-id}/resourceGroups/{resource-group-name}/providers/Microsoft.Compute/virtualMachines/{vm-name}?validating={true|false}&api-version={api-version}

ref

With a body full of Crockford approved, JSON.

Now, there are plenty of tools to help you craft this JSON, so don't fret much. Check out this (shameless plug) awesome video about how to use Visual Studio to do just that.

Trust me, I'm a professional.

Continue reading

Deploy to Azure Resource Groups using the SDK

October 31, 2015

 

Authentication

Start by adding the ADAL nuget package.

Install-Package Microsoft.IdentityModel.Clients.ActiveDirectory

Then add this file to your project:

The first line of code in your app will be… 

string token = AuthHelper.GetAuthorizationHeader();

That’s it for authentication!  

 

Setup the Resource Management Client

Start by adding the Azure Resource Management NuGet package.

Install-Package Microsoft.Azure.Management.Resources

Then drop this code into your program:

This will give you a client to make requests and create assets using the Azure Resource Manager.

 

Create a Resource Group

Next we need to create Resource Group to deploy into. Use this code with the client you just created above.

Create a Resource Deployment

I then create a deployment and set the deployment properties to contain the RAW link to those files. Finally I call CreateOrUpdateAsync method an pass all the appropriate parameters. SHH, Windows will Support OpenSSH

October 27, 2015

Microsoft loves Linux.

Who is this Microsoft? and what did you do to telnet?.. Gopher must've ate it. Open Source for life!

Those fellows who work on PowerShell must be crazy! Who'd want port 22 open on a Windows box?

Me.

No more nc.exe bro dawg! Captn_Jack and his fellow RedHat wearing brethren can finally manage Windows and Linux over thy administrator controlled port.

Supercilious really...

But why is SSH coming? I mean it's only 30 years in the making...

Well here is what the PowerShell Team has to say:

Finally, I'd like to share some background on today’s announcement, because this is the 3rd time the PowerShell team has attempted to support SSH.  The first attempts were during PowerShell V1 and V2 and were rejected.  Given our changes in leadership and culture, we decided to give it another try and this time, because we are able to show the clear and compelling customer value, the company is very supportive.  So I want to take a minute and thank all of you in the community who have been clearly and articulately making the case for why and how we should support SSH!

Emphasis put on the key point.

Install it NOW!

Trust me, I'm a professional.

Windows 10 - Show/Hide Icons in the Notification Area

October 12, 2015

Why is this hard? All I want to do is decide what icons are shown and what icons are hidden in the notification area of Windows 10... Let the red arrow show you where I mean.

Soo..... How do you do it?

  1. Hit the "Windows" key.
  2. Type: Notification
  3. Select: Notifications and action settings
  4. Choose: Select which icons appear on the taskbar
  5. Flip the slider on what you want shown or hidden

That's it! awesome...
